author: Geoffrey Chaucer
text: And so bifel, whan comen was the tym
Of Aperil, whan clothed is the med
grene, of lusty Veer the prym
The folk of Troie hir observaunces old
And to the temple, in al hir best
To herknen of Palladion the servys
ly, so many a lusty knyght,
So many a lady fressh and mayden bright,
for the seson and the fest
In beautee first so stood she, mak
Nas nevere yet seyn thing to ben preys
As was Criseyde, as folk seyde everichon
That hir bihelden in hir blak
And yet she stood ful lowe and stille allon
Byhynden other folk, in litel bred
And neigh the dore, ay under sham
Simple of atir and debonaire of cher
This Troilus, as he was wont to gid
s, lad hem up and doun
Byholding ay the ladies of the town,
Now here, now there; for no devoc{.i}oun
Hadde he to non, to reven hym his rest
But gan to preise and lakken whom hym lest
And in his walk ful faste he gan to wayten
If knyght or squyer of his compaigni
Gan for to syke, or lete his eighen baiten
On any womman that he koude espy
And seye him thus, "God woot, she slepeth soft
For love of the, whan thou turnest ful oft
"I have herd told, pardieux, of your lyvyng
And which a labour folk han in wynnyng
Of love, and in the kepyng which doutaunces;
And whan your preye is lost, woo and penaunces.
s! nyce and blynde be ye!
Ther nys nat oon kan war by other be."
And with that word he gan cast up the brow
s, "Loo! is this naught wisely spoken?"
At which the god of love gan loken row
Right for despit, and shop for to ben wroken.
For sodeynly he hitte him att
And yet as proud a pekok kan he pull
How often falleth al the effect contrair
For kaught is proud, and kaught is debonair
This Troilus is clomben on the stair
And litel weneth that he moot descenden;
But al-day faileth thing that fool
Out of the wey, so pryketh hym his corn,
Til he a lasshe have of the long
Than thynketh he, "Though I praunce al byforn
First in the trays, ful fat and new
Yet am I but an hors, and horses law
